items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible throughout the evening of Tuesday 15th April.   

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall and the River Tamar is now rising.   

Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river and around Tamarstone Bridge in the early hours of Wednesday morning.  

We expect the river to remain high throughout the night and into Wednesday morning, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by midday on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 02:00 on 16/04/2025 is higher than normal, with Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.42 m. The total forecast tide is 6.01 metres Chart Datum (2.96 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, flood impacts are possible. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Waves could cause overtopping of the beach. A small amount of water may then flow or be directed westwards along Mill Lane towards residential property in Climping Street. Wednesday afternoon's tide at 14:15 16/04/2025 is forecast to be 45 cm lower (2.51 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 16/04/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hayle, Perrancoombe Stream, Bolingey Stream, Portreath Stream, Newlyn Coombe River

items.message:
Flooding is possible throughout the evening of Tuesday 15th April.   

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall and rivers across west Cornwall continue to rise.  

Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the River Hayle and the Bolingey Stream at Cocks Bridge this evening from around 10pm.  

The main areas of concern are Penzance, Newlyn, Crowlas, Porthleven, St Ives, Hayle, Camborne, Portreath and Perranporth.   

We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night and into Wednesday morning.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages.  

This message will be updated by midday on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency

items.message:
Flooding is possible throughout the evening of Tuesday 15th April.   

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall and the River Camel is now rising.   

Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river in the early hours of Wednesday morning. 

We expect the river to remain high throughout the night and into Wednesday morning, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by midday on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 16/04/2025 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Southerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.59 m. The total forecast tide is 4.70 metres Chart Datum (2.11 mAOD) at Cowes. For 1 hour either side of high water, very minor impact flooding will affect some sea front roads, esplanades and car parks across the island. Water will be high up slipways in Cowes, affecting Medina Road and the floating bridge. In East Cowes, sea water forced up through drains may cause very minor impacts to the road at Albany Road. Wednesday afternoon's tide at 13:45 16/04/2025 is forecast to be 37 cm lower (1.74 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, we recommend that flood protection is installed at Medina Road 1 hour before high tide, water may only be 10cm below front door steps. We will remove this message by 12:00 on 16/04/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible throughout the evening of Tuesday 15th April. Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall and the River Cober is now rising.  
Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river and around Boscadjack and Helston County Bridge in the early hours of Wednesday morning.The main areas of concern are Low lying areas of Trenear, Coverack Bridges, Lowertown, Sithney Green, Helston and the Loe Valley.   
We expect the river to remain high throughout the night and into Wednesday morning.  
Take care near areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels, have staff in the area clearing blockages and we are operating the flood gate.  
This message will be updated by midday on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level at which communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to be unsettled. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 22/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 14cm. At Old Alresford, it has fallen by 17cm. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, a small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks may be struggling to operate effectively. Over the next 5 days, small amounts of rain are expected to affect Hampshire. Despite this, groundwater levels are expected to continue slowly falling. Flooding impacts will continue throughout April and likely into May. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 22/04/2025.

Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 16th April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 16th April 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level at which communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to be unsettled. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 22/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level at which communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to be unsettled. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 22/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram. This is due to persistent rainfall in December and January which has led to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. 

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation.

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 16th April 2025, or as the situation changes.
